comment_body.2:
I've got a fun one for you. Looking for a "fun" car with only a few stipulations.

​

  • Location: Midwest US
  • Price range: Up to $55k
  • Criteria: FUN CAR
    • Manual strongly strongly preferred
    • Must be interesting
    • Prefer not a major project
    • Must not be at risk of significantly depreciating in.... maybe 5 years.
    • That's.... about it.

​

Here's what I've been considering:

  • 1st Generation NSX
  • CTS-V Wagon
  • 964/993 Porsche - probably limiting my options for specific model/condition due to the relatively high prices across the range
  • Morgan Three-Wheeler - wild card! Not practical or reliable, but definitely would tick the "fun" box
  • A very nice Miata or Classic Mini - I've already got one of each, but these are both cars where you can always use another!

Mostly ruled out:

  • Mk4 Supra - not my style, not the right time for the market (in my opinion)
  • FD RX-7 - Not especially interesting to me, but they are gorgeous.
  • older Viper - not really my style, but it does fit the criteria.
  • Elise/Exige - I'm not looking for a track car - I'd buy another Miata or BMW first.
  • Alfa 4C - Automatic :(
  • Jeep Forward Control - if we're talking weird, might as well throw a truck in there, but not really sure this fits the "fun" bill enough.

​

Really curious if anyone can come up with something that isn't on the list. My friends and I have spent hours discussing this and haven't come up with much more than what's there. Thanks for any interesting suggestions!
comment_body.3:
So I already have my dream car, now I'm looking for my second car that will do everything a 760hp RWD mustang can't do.

Things like drive in bad/cold weather, be comfortable cruising, reliable, not wake the neighbors, etc.
comment_body.4:
I’m looking for sporty, fun to drive family hauler with great handling and a higher-end interior. I’m currently driving a 2013 Focus ST that I bought as a temporary car between my much beloved RX-8 (love/hate kinda thing) and a Model 3 (the RX-8 died a year before the 3 was released). I wound up really loving the ST despite the cheaper interior, road noise, and outdated tech (by today’s standards) and have driven it for the past 6 years.

But after having a kid a year ago, I have to have the driver’s seat uncomfortably forward to fit her car seat and I’m ready for something a little more on the luxury side. I’m open to sedans with cargo capacity, wagons, hatchbacks, and small SUVs/crossovers so long as they’re still sporty. I also tend to hold onto cars for 8 or 10 years so I’d like something that’s going to last awhile. Lastly, if it’s an ICE car, I do enjoy tinkering so I’d like something with reasonable aftermarket parts availability.

Thanks for your thoughts!

• Location: Southern California • Price range: $40-$55k for ICE but willing to go to $65k for electric • Lease or Buy: Buy • New or used: Open, but would rather get more value with something gently used • Type of vehicle: Sporty luxury, need cargo capacity • Must haves: 4 doors, trunk space, enough rear seat room for a car seat, leather, excellent infotainment/tech • Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): manual but I recognize that’s a tall order and I’ll be fine with auto • Intended use: Daily Driver, Family Car, occasional mountain drives in the twisties • Vehicles you've already considered: Audi A5 Fastback, A5 Allroad, eTron, Model S, Model Y, Porsche Macan S, BMW 3 series • Is this your 1st vehicle: No • Do you need a Warranty: No • Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes • Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

2019-2020 Volvo v60 r design Upcoming mk8 Volkswagen GTI / R Audi S4 BMW M2 Tesla Model 3 Mustang GT performance pack 2 Camaro SS 1le

I have moments where i want something practical like a Volvo and save up for a dedicated weekend car. Or just get a sports car and deal with the impracticality.

comment_body.16:
Location: (Specify your country or region): Southern California

Price range: (Minimum-Maximum in your local currency): $7-15k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: (Truck, Car, Sports Car, Sedan, Crossover, SUV, Racecar, Luxury etc.): Convertible

Must haves: (4x4, AWD, Fuel efficient, Navigation, Turbo, V8, V6, Trunk space, Smooth ride, Leather etc.): N/A, ideally bluetooth to play music but can always swap out the head unit

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Auto

Intended use: (Daily Driver, Family Car, Weekend Car, Track Toy, Project Car, Work Truck, Off roading etc.): Daily

Vehicles you've already considered: Solara, SC 430, IS 350C, Miata

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: (fluids, alternator, battery, brake pads etc): No

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: (engine and transmission, timing belt/chains, body work, suspension etc ): No

Additional Notes: Here's one slightly off the wall - I've been looking at getting a convertible for a while since I sold my m235i due to working from home. I've totally fallen for the LC 500 drop top. I know it's not the fastest or best handling, but I think it looks fantastic and coupled with Lexus quality and reliability, it really seems like a fantastic car.

But there's no way in hell I'm buying a six figure car. So, I figure why not wait 4-5 years for the depreciation to set in. Right now, 2018 LC 500s can be had for ~$65k, so I figure within 4-5 years the drop top should hit $45-55k. In the meantime, I can sock away some money every month and just buy a cheap, reliable convertible like a Solara (lol) or SC 430. I don't drive a ton anyway and who knows when the office opens back up. By spending $7-12k on a car, it won't be the most fun driving experience for a few years, but opens up the possibility of snagging an LC 500. But who knows - plans change!

Are there any other cheap, reliable convertibles I should consider? I think a Miata will be too small for my purposes.

comment_body.18: Generally speaking, which car is a better bang for you buck, a brand new C43 AMG or an Audi S3? Looking to upgrade finally after my G37 took a poop on me. Any input is very appreciated.
comment_body.19: I love my S5, but it’s a coupe without much legroom. Even with the sportback variant l feel like it might be a little small for what your looking for.
comment_body.20: Selling my ILX 14’ manual. Really wanted to hop into another manual more comfortable for commuting when I go back to work but also road trips. I have an s2000 as my summer car so not looking for extreme performance, just some pep. I was going to wait until I had to go back to work, but stumbled upon a manual accord sport (2017) checks off some the items, except it has some downgrades cloth, no heated seats, no sunroof. But the manual was effortless and the ride comfy. I’m torn,I could save cash buying it over waiting and perhaps getting something more luxurious or more techy, other cars on my mind have been Elantra N, when it comes out, outback XT, cx-5, maybe a certified used luxury. All the new vehicles have a bunch of annoyances, all touchscreen interfaces, CVTS, underpowered engines, stop start.
comment_body.21: Best all around practical performance car would be the Civic Type R ... nothing else compares to the practicality, performance and fun factor for $40K (CAD)!

comment_body.23:
Location: USA (if the deal is good and legit, I'd have it shipped to me)

Price range: $7,000-$15,000. Depending on if a price jump would make a world of difference in the long run, I can go up to $25,000.

Lease or Buy: Buy, specifically with cash all at once.

New or used: With my budget, probably used. Open to new though.

Type of vehicle: Car/Sedan/Hatchback

Must haves: reliable, good mpg, not too expensive to maintain- so whatever average maintenance costs are or better, comfortable drivers seat, plausible chance/ability to last 200,000-300,000+ miles.

Desired transmission: Automatic

Intended use: Daily Driver, assuming nothing major changes in my life, I drive less than 2,000 miles a year.

Vehicles you've already considered: deciding between 2011-2019 years for an Accord, Civic, Camry, Corolla, Golf.

Is this your 1st vehicle: Yes

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No. One day, maybe.

Additional Notes:

Horsepower: I'm far from a speed demon. Enough power to get onto highways/roads and up to speed fast enough without putting myself or others in danger is enough for me.

Fun to drive: I don't know what that is.

Drive type: FWD preferred for cost. Even though the car will be used in all four seasons, I can make due.

On top of the "must haves" I listed above, I also have some more things I'd look for in a car more as a "this would be nice to have, but I don't really need it" kind of mindset. If there's a really good car out there that doesn't have all of these things, I WOULD still consider it.

Superfluous criteria: heated seats, android auto, bluetooth, quiet cabin (no rattling or squeaking, minimal road noise), steering wheel that can hold a line (not constantly micro-correcting), (reasonably) smooth ride.

Mega superfluous criteria: Backup camera, parking assist, lane keep assist, lane departure warning, auto-merge, heated steering wheel, fog lights, sun/moonroof, struts on hood, spacious trunk.

comment_body.40:
Is a 2017 BMW 330i a decent car?

I’m looking into various (somewhat “luxury”) cars and stumbled across a 2017 BMW 330i. It has about 25k miles and is a CPO from a dealership for roughly 20k.

I was curious what your thoughts are on this car? I don’t really mind that it’s the lower end of BMWs and I’m not really set on this specific one, but comparing it to other models such as Audis, Infiniti’s, etc. it’s cheaper and the fact it’s a CPO means it comes with a decent warranty for a few more years.

My question is, is this a decent car? I’ve had car troubles in the past and understand that this one will be spendy to repair which is why I’m banking on the warranty.

Any thoughts or ideas would he greatly appreciated. I know NOTHING about cars and not much family to ask so I resort to Google and Reddit. Appreciate any insight!

comment_body.49: is there a significance for these paint jobs?https://pbs.twimg.com/card_img/1327263022599979010/2RbD8nwQ?format=jpg&name=medium
comment_body.51:
Location: Colorado Mountains

Price range: $18k-24k

Lease or Buy: Open to Either

New or used:

Type of vehicle: SUV/CUV

Must haves: 4WD/AWD & Bluetooth. I could care less about anything else. Seriously...it could have hand crank windows.

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Either

Intended use: Daily Driver / MTB Transport / Backcountry Camper

Vehicles you've already considered: Crosstrek/Compass/Renegade/Cherokee/Forester/Tiguan

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: Undecided

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Suspension, but nothing else.

Additional Notes:

I am hoping to land a job here in the near future. I've been out of work for a while. I moved to the mountains of Colorado and sold my beloved and reliable Mazdaspeed3 because it couldn't handle the unplowed roads here. I bought an 06 Jeep Liberty as a cheap snow beater and daily driver and it has been a NIGHTMARE of a vehicle. Just the worst thing I've ever owned. BUT... its super amazing in the snow and on the jeep roads out here. Hands down the most capable vehicle I've owned when its running and things arent falling off of it.

The moment I get a job I'm shoving it off a cliff and heading to the dealership. I'm between leasing and buying right now, with leasing obviously being a new vehicle and buying being something used. I've been looking heavily at the Crosstrek as a replacement, but its dangerously slow and underpowered for climbing these mountain passes. I love that its got high reliability marks. I would consider leasing the Crosstrek Sport, but honestly having driven the Forester with the 2.5L engine...its not much better. Merging into traffic with either of these vehicles feels chancy and climbing hills with 3 bikes and a week's worth of camping gear seems worse.

I'm looking for something with the capability of the liberty and the reliability of the subaru and the power of something made this century. The Touareg and Tiguan appeal to me. I looooooved my '06 Rabbit, but I don't know how they fare offroad and I really want something that can get to my favorite campsites in the national forest near Buena Vista.
